On Mar 19, 2008, at 9:18 AM, Sebastien Lambla wrote:

>
> A resource has a=
 representation which you can GET. A resource can  
> have several represen=
tations, XML, HTML, Image etc.
> With a POST and PUT you sent (or can sent)=
 an entity within the  
> body, to a resource.
> A PUT doesn=92t send an en=
tity to a resource. It sends an entity to a  
> url that may be a resource.=
 If it is a resource, as per the spec,  
> =93the enclosed entity should be=
 considered as a modified version of  
> the one residing on the origin ser=
ver=94.

Thanks for catching me.  You are right. The target is a URI and no=
t a  
resource.

> I think I fail to see the distinction between entity and=
 resource,  
> while i certainly see the difference between a representatio=
n of a  
> resource and a resource...

I guess I went too far with the dist=
inction.

Subbu


--Apple-Mail-6-4691473
